1.0   Executive Summary

DPS Mopjave LLC, (DPS) operates the Mojave Cogeneration Company, LP (MCC) cogeneration facility in Boron, California.  DPS recently purchased the facility from U.S. Borax.  The facility operates one Westinghouse aero-derivative combustion turbine generator (CTG) with a maximum nominal gross output of 53 megawatts (MW) (43 MW electricity plus 10 MW steam).  The CTG burns pipeline quality sweet dry natural gas exclusively.  It is equipped with a Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) system and ammonia injection for the control of nitrogen oxide (NOx) emissions.  Anhydrous ammonia is supplied to the SCR from a 12,000-gallon storage tank.  The working capacity of the tank is limited by administrative controls to 85 percent capacity, or approximately 10,500 gallons (approximately 60,400 pounds). 

The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia stored and used at the DPS facility of 60,400 pounds exceeds the threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds for regulation under the federal Risk Management Plan (RMP) (40 Code of Federal Regulations [CFR] Part 68), the 10,000-pound threshold for regulation under the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA?s) Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation (29 CFR 1910.112) and the 500-pound threshold for regulation under the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) RMP program.  DPS has developed this plan to document the plans and programs DPS has in place to comply with these three regulatory programs.

The storage and use of anhydrous ammonia at the DPS facility meets the requirements for a Program Level 3 facility under the federal and CalARP RMP programs, based on the storage of 10,500 gallons (60,400 pounds) of anhydrous ammonia, the potential to impact an off-site public receptor due to the worst-case release of ammonia from the process, and a release of ammonia within the last five years.  The release occurred under prior ownership of the facility and details of the release are not known

.  It is estimated that approximately 20 pounds of anhydrous ammonia was released and there are no known offsite consequences attributed to the release.

U.S. Borax had in place a CalARP / RMP plan for the facility when DPS acquired the facility.  DPS has elected to develop a new combined CalARP / RMP / PSM plan that reflects DPSs' plans and procedures, and also reflects the administrative changes such as contact information, responsibility and ownership.  This new plan constitutes a 5-year update of the RMP / PSM plan for the Mojave Cogeneration Company facility.

1.1 Accident Release Prevention Program and Emergency Response Policy

DPS has a commitment to worker and public safety.  DPS is committed to operating and maintaining all of the processes in a safe and responsible manner.  DPS has implemented a combination of accident release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of its employees and the public, as well as to protect the environment.  DPS is committed to minimize the risk of a release of a hazardous material, and if a release occurs, to minimize the potential impact to employees, the public, and the environment.  DPS management is committed to providing appropriate training to employees, and coordinating response activities, as necessary, with the local emergency response providers to ensure a safe operation.

1.2 Covered Process, Substance, and Quantity

This combined CalARP / RMP / OSHA PSM plan is for the anhydrous ammonia unloading, storage, and handling process at the DPS facility in Boron, California.  The ammonia is stored in an above ground storage tank and is injected into the SCR systems for the control of NOx emissions from the one CTG at the facility.  The covered chemical is ammonia, Chemical Abstract Service (CAS) number 7664-41-7.  The tank has a design capacity of 12,000 gallons (61,800 pounds), and an operating capacity due to administrative controls of 10,500 gallons (60,400 pounds).

1.4 Process and Equipment 

Description

The ammonia storage and handling system at DPS is comprised of a single storage tank with vaporizer, pressure regulators, dilution skid with two air blowers, and distribution piping to the SCR catalyst bed.  The system has a NOx analyzer and ammonia flow controllers to regulate the flow of ammonia to the SCR.  The ammonia tank has redundant pressure relief valves to ensure safe operation of the tank.  The ammonia tank is a horizontally-oriented cylindrical tank.  The tank is constructed of carbon steel which is compatible with anhydrous ammonia.  The tank has a design capacity of 12,000 gallons, and is limited by administrative controls to an operating capacity of 10,500 gallons.  The tank is equipped with a deluge system that will flood the tank (externally)

with copious amounts of water in the event of an ammonia release.  The tank is installed within a concrete containment structure that will contain up to 12,000 gallons of liquid.  A simplified process flow diagram is shown as Figure 1-1.  A more detailed description of the equipment is provided in Section 2.0.  Equipment photographs are shown in Appendix A.

1.5 Program Level 3 Prevention Program

1.5.1 Process Safety Information

DPS relies on the chemical supplier for chemical safety information.  The ammonia supplier is Pacific Diazo, of Bakersfield, California.  A Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for anhydrous ammonia is included in Appendix B.  Regulatory citations for elements of the Program Level 3 Prevention Program are from 19 California Code of Regulations (CCR) ?2760.

1.5.2 Process Hazards Analysis

A team composed of DPS and ENSR staff conducted a Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) on August 1, 2006 for the anhydrous ammonia process at the facility.  The team consisted of individuals experienced in operation and maintenance of the anhydrous ammonia system, hazards analysis, safety management, environmental health and safety issues, and performance of a PHA using appropriate techniques.  A complete description of the PHA process is provided in Section 4.0, and the PHA worksheets are provided in Appendix C.

A combined ?What-If? and ?Guideword? approach was used to evaluate potential hazards in the ammonia system at the facility.  Both approaches are approved methodology for conducting a PHA under the CalARP, RMP and OSHA PSM programs.  The objective of these methodologies is to identify potential deviations from normal operating conditions that could lead to a release of a regulated substance.  

The PHA Team broke the ammonia process down into three ?nodes?: unloading of ammonia, ammonia storage and delivery to the SCR, and general site hazards.  These nodes were broken down further into elements for evaluation.  Elements are usually individual components

that could fail, such as a valve, pump, or hose.  Of the 37 elements defined for evaluation, the PHA Team did not identify any scenarios with the three highest criticality rankings of ?Unacceptable?, ?Undesirable?, or ?Acceptable with Controls? which would require mitigation.  Twenty-four elements were rated as ?Acceptable? and 13 had ratings of ?Not a Hazard?.  The PHA Team determined that no additional mitigation was warranted to reduce the risk from these scenarios.

1.5.3 Operating Procedures

The DPS is a commercial power plant, and as such, has developed Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for all of the operations necessary to ensure safe and reliable operation of the facility.  The SOPs constitute a significant volume of written documentation, and the SOPs are routinely evaluated and updated.  The SOPs are incorporated by reference into this RMP / PSM.

1.5.4 Training

The DPS has implemented a training program for all employees covering the anhydrous ammonia process as required by ?2760.4.  The purpose of the training program is to ensure that highly hazardous chemicals (i.e. ammonia) are handled in a consistent and safe manner and to have operators trained in the safe handling of chemicals at the facility.  An effective training program will help operators understand the nature and causes of problems arising from process operations and will increase employee awareness with respect to the hazards involved in handling ammonia.

DPS trains employees using a combination of classroom, on-the-job training, and independent study.  The training program includes initial training, refresher training, documentation, and periodic reviews of effectiveness.  Employees receive general safety training during new employee orientation, including chemical safety-related training programs such as hazard communication and use of personal protective equipment.  Emergency response training including evacuation is provided to all employees to ensure that plant personnel are abl

e to respond effectively to an emergency or potential emergency situation.  Additional training in hazardous materials management is provided for those employees who will be exposed to hazardous materials in the workplace.  The level of additional training will vary depending upon job function of the employee.  Specific training for effective implementation of the RMP / PSM is also provided to employees, as required to satisfy their job function.  Training is also provided to contractors to ensure they will function safely while working onsite.

A copy of the current Employee Training program is incorporated into this CalARP RMP plan by reference.  The Employee Training program in effect on the date this CalARP RMP plan was developed is included in Appendix J.

1.5.5 Mechanical Integrity Program

The Mechanical Integrity program defines the procedures and responsibilities associated with the maintenance of the mechanical integrity of the anhydrous ammonia process equipment to ensure it meets design specifications, is installed correctly, and operates safely as required by ?2760.5.

The facility maintenance staff conducts routine inspection, testing, and replacement of the critical components in the ammonia process.  These activities are reviewed by the Environmental Safety Manager.  The written Mechanical Integrity program provides a description of the basic inspection and testing procedures that are utilized at the facility.  Replacement or refurbishment of equipment after a specified use period is also documented.

The facility has devised a specific maintenance program for the ammonia system.  This program consists of the following:

* A daily system log to record operational parameters of the system;

* Periodic routine operational inspection and testing;

* A continuing maintenance and repair program; and

* Keeping records of inspections in a location accessible to employees.

A copy of the current Mechanical Integrity program is incorporated into this RMP / P

SM plan by reference.  The Mechanical Integrity program in effect on the date the RMP / PSM was developed is included in Appendix J.

1.5.6 Management of Change

DPS has a Management of Change (MOC) procedure that defines the procedures and responsibilities associated with MOC as required by ?2760.6.  This procedure provides a systematic approach for initiating, authorizing, and implementing modifications to the anhydrous ammonia process at the facility.

The MOC procedure covers the design, maintenance, and operation of the anhydrous ammonia process.  This procedure must be applied whenever changes are made to the physical characteristics of the plant as well as for changes in the operation of the process that have the potential to affect adversely other processes at the plant.  

A copy of the current MOC procedure is incorporated into this RMP / PSM plan by reference.  The MOC procedure in effect on the date the RMP / PSM was developed is included in Appendix J.

1.5.7 Pre-Startup Safety Review

The Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) procedure defines the procedures and responsibilities associated with the PSSR at DPS, as required by ?2760.7.  The purpose for the PSSR is to ensure that certain important considerations have been addressed before a covered hazardous substance (i.e., anhydrous ammonia) is introduced into a new or modified process.  These procedures help to ensure that adequate safety measures are in place and are operational.  A pre-startup safety review must be conducted on all new and significantly modified covered processes prior to the introduction of hazardous materials.  The PSSR procedure for the facility ensures that:

* Construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications; 

* Safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate;

* A PHA has been completed on new facilities;

* The MOC procedure has been utilized for new or modified facilities; and 

* Training of affected employees has bee

n completed. 

A copy of the current PSSR procedure is incorporated into this RMP / PSM plan by reference.  The PSSR in effect on the date this RMP / PSM plan was developed is included in Appendix J.

1.5.8 Compliance Audits

Compliance audits of the CalARP RMP program at a facility are required by ?2760.8 to be performed at least every three years.  A compliance audit was conducted for DPS by Processes Unlimited International, Inc. in January 2006.  A copy of the audit report is attached in Appendix D.  The findings of the audit have been addressed in this RMP.

In addition, because of the recent purchase of the facility from U.S. Borax and to establish a baseline for the equipment condition, DPS had Pacific Diazo (the ammonia supplier) perform a comprehensive physical inspection of the ammonia system equipment in June 2006.  The inspection report is also included in Appendix D.  DPS implemented the corrective actions recommended by Pacific Diazo shortly after the report was received.

DPS has developed a Compliance Audit Checklist (adapted from the EPA guidance document) for future Compliance Audits.  The Checklist is included in Appendix J.

1.5.9 Incident Investigation

DPS has in place an Incident Investigation procedure that defines the procedures and responsibilities associated with the investigation of the causes of incidents involving covered hazardous materials (i.e., anhydrous ammonia) at DPS as required by ?2760.9.  DPS management understands that a significant number of accidents can be eliminated and that the potential for a large release of ammonia can be reduced by a consistent, thorough investigation of all releases and near-miss accidents.  This procedure provides the basis for those investigations.  

Any employee who is aware of a release, incident, or a near-miss involving the anhydrous ammonia system has the responsibility to report the incident to the Plant Manager/ designee.  The Plant Manager will then organize an Incident Investigation Comm

ittee and complete the Supervisors Incident Investigation Report.

Hazards identified by employee suggestions can also be reviewed by the Incident Investigation Committee.  These suggestions may be made in writing or in person, directly to an Incident Investigation Committee representative, or anonymously through employee suggestion boxes.  Documentation of corrective measures implemented to mitigate hazardous conditions will be maintained in the administrative office and may be reviewed by any employee requesting such information.

A copy of the current Incident Investigation procedure is incorporated into this RMP /PSM plan by reference.  The Incident Investigation procedure in effect on the date the RMP / PSM was developed is included in Appendix J.

1.5.10 Employee Participation Plan

An Employee Participation program has been established at DPS to ensure that employees of the facility can take an active role in the prevention of hazardous chemical spills at the facility as required by ?2760.10. As supporters of this program, DPS management is committed to:

* Consult with employees on the conduct and development of PHAs, and on the development of the other elements of the RMP and PSM.

* Provide access to the PHA and to other information required to be developed by the standard to employees without regard to potential trade secret status of such information.  

A copy of the current Employee Participation Plan is incorporated into this RMP / PSM plan by reference.  The Employee Participation Plan in effect on the date the RMP / PSM plan was developed is included in Appendix J.

1.5.11 Hot Work

DPS has developed a Hot Work Permit program that complies with OSHA?s requirements codified as 29 CFR 1910.119 and Title 8 CCR 5189.  The program requires that a Hot Work Permit be issued for hot work at the facility, and that the permit documents that the fire prevention and protection requirements of the rule are implemented prior to initiating hot work.  The permit wi

ll also list the date that the work is authorized and the equipment on which the hot work is to be performed.

A copy of the current Hot Work Permit program is incorporated into this RMP / PSM plan by reference.  The Hot Work Permit program in effect on the date the RMP / PSM plan was developed is included in Appendix J.

1.5.12 Contractor Safety

DPS relies on two-way communication between DPS employees and contractors to ensure a safe working environment.  DPS requires that contractors be properly trained prior to being allowed onsite, and requires that the contractors undergo site-specific safety training prior to starting work.  The contractor is required to obtain a Hot Work Permit from the Control Room prior to beginning work involving live electricity, pressurized pipelines or other energy-related hazards, and are required to use lock out / tag out and confined space entry procedures, as appropriate.  The contractor is also required to provide training to DPS employees if the contractor brings onsite any chemicals or materials in the course of their work that may expose facility employees to hazards that were not previously onsite.  

1.6 5-Year Accident History

The facility had a release of anhydrous ammonia on February 1, 2005, prior to its purchase by DPS from U.S. Borax.  The time of the release is unknown.  The release occurred due to a failure of the ammonia relief valve on the ammonia injection skid.  When the leak was discovered, the relief valve was immediately isolated using a block valve upstream.  The faulty relief valve was subsequently replaced.  The release is estimated at 20 pounds of ammonia.  There were no offsite consequences attributed to the release.

There are no additional known releases from the ammonia process in the last five years.

1.7 Emergency Response Plan

DPSs? Emergency Response Plan includes the following core elements:

* Specific actions to be taken in response to an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia;

* Procedures

to notify local and public agencies including the Kern County Fire Department, the Office of Emergency Services (OES), and the National Response Center, as necessary;

* Information on emergency health care;

* Information regarding the emergency response training of employees; and

* A list of the other federal and state requirements to which this facility is subject.

This RMP / PSM has been coordinated with the Kern County Fire Department (Station 17 - Boron).  In addition, the facility has an agreement with Edwards Air Force Base for emergency response support. Hazardous material (HazMat) response is from the Kern County Fire Department in Bakersfield.  The current version of the Emergency Response Plan is provided in Appendix J.

1.8 Offsite Consequence Analysis

In light of security concerns, and consistent with EPA policy, discussion of the Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA) has been omitted from the text of this RMP / PSM.  The OCA is provided in Appendix E.

1.9 RMP Registration

This RMP has been registered electronically with EPA, as required.  A copy of the registration is included in Appendix H.

1.10 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

DPS has recently conducted a thorough 3-year RMP compliance audit, a thorough safety inspection of the ammonia tank and distribution system, and a comprehensive PHA for the ammonia process.  DPS took corrective action immediately for each deficiency identified in these reviews.  As of the date of preparation of this RMP / PSM plan, there are no outstanding corrective actions.

During the development of the OCA for this RMP / PSM, DPS evaluated the potential consequences of a worst-case release of ammonia.  Based on this evaluation, DPS determined that it was necessary to install a containment and water deluge system on the Boron facility anhydrous ammonia tank.  DPS made this decision for three reasons:

1. General industry practice is to install a water deluge system on anhydrous ammonia tanks at power plants.

2. A cont

ainment vessel will contain the movement of spilled anhydrous ammonia while it evaporates, and will also collect a portion of the ammonia saturated deluge water, thereby reducing the surface area of the ammonia spill and limiting emissions of ammonia.

3. The entire town of Boron, including the Fire Department station, is within the significant impact threshold radius for the worst-case spill.

4. The Kern County Fire Department Hazardous Material (HazMat) response team is located in Bakersfield, approximately 90 miles away.  Consequently, there would likely be at least a 1.5 hour response time for arrival of the HazMat team if a release were to occur. 

The deluge system mitigates a release of ammonia by absorbing the ammonia in copious amounts of water.  This will lower the vapor pressure of the ammonia, reduce the evolution of vapor to the atmosphere from the resultant aqueous solution, and spread the duration of the release to atmosphere over a much longer period of time.  This mitigation will effectively lower the concentration of ammonia at offsite receptors.

DPS completed construction of the containment structure and deluge system in December 2006.  The deluge system is designed for a flow rate of 0.25 gallons per minute per square foot of area with a total flow rate requirement of 296.8 gallons per minute.  The containment structure has a capacity of approximately 12,000 gallons and provides containment for the ammonia-saturated deluge water captured by the containment system.  The containment structure limits the surface area of the ammonia solution to the dimensions of the structure, and thereby reduces the release rate of ammonia into the atmosphere (relative to an uncontained pool of ammonia-saturated deluge water), which in turn reduces the resulting ammonia concentration at potential offsite receptors.
